titlStmt.titl: The CHAPTER II Study: Congenital Heart Adolescents Participating in Transition Evaluation Research

citation.biblCit: Mackie, Andrew; Rempel, Gwen; Kovacs, Adrienne; Kaufman, Miriam; Rankin, Kathryn; Jelen, Ahlexxi; Manlhiot, Cedric; Anthony, Samantha; Magill-Evans, Joyce; Nicholas, David; Sananes, Renee; Oechslin, Erwin; Dragieva, Dimi; Mustafa, Sonila; Williams, Elina; Schuh, Michelle; McCrindle, Brian, 2016, "The CHAPTER II Study: Congenital Heart Adolescents Participating in Transition Evaluation Research", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10907, UAL Dataverse, V3

titlStmt.titl: The CHAPTER II Study: Congenital Heart Adolescents Participating in Transition Evaluation Research

stdyInfo.abstract: This project will determine whether a nurse-led transition intervention program is better at preparing teens with Congenital Heart Disease (CHD) to independently manage their medical care, compared to the care that is currently provided. The most important finding of this study will be whether or not these teens subsequently attend the adult cardiology clinic that specializes in CHD problems, and the timing of when they attend.

sumDscr.dataKind: Questionnaire data; Clinical data; Qualitative data
sumDscr.universe: 16 and 17 year old adolescents with moderate or complex congenital heart disease (CHD).

dataColl.frequenc: Questionnaire data will be collected at 1, 6, 12, and 18 months. Chart reviews will occur at baseline, and excess time to first ACHD clinic appointment will be accessed 12 and 24 months post enrollment. Cardiologist's assessment of readiness to transition will be tracked at the first appointment post-enrollment. Qualitative data will be collected after each session (nursing intervention log) and 1 week post session (texts and emails).
dataColl.sampProc: The sample size is based on testing group differences in excess time to adult congenital heart disease (ACHD) care, with a two-sided log-rank test. A sample size of 60 patients per group (120 total) will allow detection of a difference between 90 and 70 %, the proportions that have attended their first ACHD clinic appointment by the end of the observation period in the intervention and usual care groups, respectively, with 80+% power, accounting for the 'design effect' due to the cluster randomization of the trial. Patients were assigned to groups through block randomization with the unit of randomization being week.

sources.dataSrc: Transition Readiness Assessment Questionnaire (TRAQ); MyHeart Scale; Williams Scale

dataColl.collMode: Self-administered questionnaire: Paper; Self-administered questionnaire: Web-based; Self-administered writings and/or diaries; Chart review
dataColl.actMin: There will be follow-up communication if questionnaires are not returned.
dataColl.conOps: Field validation is built into REDCap data collection forms.

anlyInfo.dataAppr: The control group was less responsive than the intervention group.

setAvail.avlStatus: Data is not available because the study is still ongoing.

useStmt.conditions: Access to deidentified data may be permitted for external researchers, with limitations. The data producer determines access on a case-by-case basis. Contact the data producer directly to discuss terms and conditions of access.

othrStdyMat.relStdy: Evaluation of Novel Transition for Youth with Congenital Heart Disease (CHAPTER I)
The CHAPTER III Study of Young Adolescents: Congenital Heart Adolescents Participating in Transition Evaluation Research

citation.biblCit: Mackie, AS, Rempel, GR, Kovacs, AH, Kaufman, M, Rankin, KN, Jelen, A, Manlhiot, C, Anthony, SJ, Magill-Evans, J, Nicholas, D, Sananes, R, Oechslin, E, Dragieva, D, Mustafa, S, Williams, E, Schuh, M, McCrindle, BW (2016). A cluster randomized trial of a transition intervention for adolescents with congenital heart disease: rationale and design of the CHAPTER 2 study. BMC Cardiovascular Disorders, 16, 127.
